isaInvestigation.title: Investigation
isaInvestigation.description: Created using the MetaboLights Online Editor (MOE)

studies.title: Botanical collections as an opportunity to explore nature through the time: An untargeted metabolomic study in historical and modern Nicotiana leaves
studies.description: The living and dried specimens in botanical collections play an important role in society for scientific and recreational purposes, offering the opportunity to obtain both macroscopic and molecular information for individual plants, ecosystems, and environmental studies. Untargeted metabolomics is an analytical approach that permits the simultaneous study of multiple small molecules present in an organism, which allows us to statistically compare different conditions of interest. Metabolomic approaches have been used on living specimens in botanical collections, but, until now, not on historical dried material. Using the Nicotiana genus herbaceous plant (tobacco) as a case study, we propose an untargeted metabolomic study to evaluate the potential of dried historical specimens as a source of metabolomic information on the past. The metabolomic profile from polar and less-polar/apolar aqueous extracts of four modern handmade tobacco cigars (split into wrapper, binder, and filler leaves), and a set of eight late-19th to early-20th century tobacco specimens (seven tobacco leaves and one snuff powder) from the collection of the Royal Botanical Gardens at Kew (London, UK) were analysed by liquid chromatography coupled to high resolution mass spectrometry. Results showed a wide range of polar and less-polar/apolar molecules which are preserved in dried botanical material, providing information optimal for metabolomic studies. The metabolomic profiles of historical dried samples were distinct enough to classify as Nicotiana tabacum or Nicotiana rustica, and showed differences based on geographic provenance or product transformation/processing. Statistical models based on the molecular data from the historical material permitted us to validate the labelling of the historical collection, which identified one possible mislabelled specimen and offered some clues as to the species of one unknown Nicotiana sample. Finally, metabolomic differences in profiles between Nicotiana tabacum and modern cigars showed that both share a large proportion of their metabolomic profile, where molecular differences could be possibly associated with both location of growth and anthropogenic transformation suffered by the plant in the last two centuries. This study demonstrates that dry botanical collections are a feasible source of information, and, if applied to a large set of individuals, conclusions may be drawn about the possible evolution and anthropogenic modification over time in plant material. The results are significant for disciplines interested in the history of plants, such as botany, history and archaeology.

people.affiliation: School of archaeology and ancient history, University of Leicester

publications.title: Botanical collections as an opportunity to explore nature through the time: An untargeted metabolomic study in historical and modern Nicotiana leaves
publications.authorList: Diego Badillo-Sanchez, Maria Serrano Ruber, Anna Davies-Barrett, Donald JL Jones, Sarah Inskip

protocols.name: Sample collection
protocols.description:
Historical samples:

To evaluate the potential of dry botanical samples as a source of metabolomic data for the analysis of plant history, and to assess if, in this type of material, there is enough chemical information preserved to distinguish between species and location as have been identified in studies on modern living plants, a metabolomic study was performed by using historical dry samples of 2 different Nicotiana species: Nicotiana rustica (N.R.) and Nicotiana tabacum (N.T.). These are currently thought to be the most frequently used tobacco plants in the past[1].


An in-situ micro-sampling of 8 Nicotiana species from the Royal Botanical Gardens of Kew (London, UK) was performed. The specimens selected represented Nicotiana tabacum and Nicotiana rustica species plus 1 specimen of unknown species. All but 1 of these samples were preserved as dried leaves, with the other being a snuff (powder) tobacco (see Fig. 1 and Table 1 in the paper associated with this study). The micro-sampling was performed on plant areas where there would be minimal impact to the integrity of the plant, endeavouring to take material that was already loose. Less than 200 mg were extracted from each sample and stored in individual pre-labelled containers for analysis (for reference, 1 single dry leaf of N.T. weighs >5 g).


Modern samples:

Tobacco is a product that results from the cutting of leaves from a Nicotiana genus plant. Depending on the drying process (curation), size reduction (powdering, cutting, etc.), and consumption, different products are produced for the market, i.e., cigars, chewing tobacco, cigarettes, snuff, etc. Cigars are one of the most famous tobacco products formed by rolling up different leaves after being cut from the plant and dried naturally with no use of heat. This produces a set of dry leaves that, when combusted, produce a specific smoke with specific sensorial characteristics according to the chemical composition of the leaves.


To contrast the molecular composition found in the dry Nicotiana tabacum samples from the historical collection with modern samples, 4 different handmade modern cigars manufactured from Nicotiana tabacum leaves were purchased from a recognized online provider. Only cigars were selected, as the lack of curation with heat means they are in a similar condition to samples found in historical collections, as opposed to cigarette tobacco which is treated/curated or modified after harvesting. Each cigar was manually dissected, and the different leaves were separated into wrapper, binder, and filler, with each leaf considered as a single sample. Individual leaves were collected in pre-labelled containers for a total of 12 samples (see Fig. 2 and Table 2 in the paper associated with this study).


Ref:

[1] Hughes J. (2003). Learning to Smoke: Tobacco Use in the West, University of Chicago Press, Chicago, IL.

protocols.name: Extraction
protocols.description:
Before extraction, all modern cigar samples were placed in a convection electric oven at 60 °C for 48 h and later left to acclimatise at room temperature to better mimic the possible composition present in the historical samples by reducing the possible volatiles present in the modern tobacco. Modern cigar samples were ground in an electric spice grinder for 25 s to homogenize and reduce the leaves’ dimensions.


Metabolite extractions of the different historical and modern Nicotiana samples were performed as follows: 1) 20 mg of dry leaves were placed in a 1.5 ml plastic tube with an O-ring cap and 6 ceramic beads of 3 mm diameter and 500 μl of methanol were added. 2) Tubes were vortexed for 10 s and then placed in a BeadBlaster 24 Microtube homogenizer (Benchmark Scientific Inc., USA) for a sequence of 20 s of homogenization at high speed plus 25 s of pause repeated in 6 cycles. 3) Tubes were centrifuged for 5 min at 10,500 RCF. 4) The supernatant was pipetted out and placed in a new plastic 1.5 ml tube with a cellulose acetate membrane filter of 0.22 μm. 5) 500 μl of water was added to the initial sample tube with the precipitate and the beads, and steps 2-4 repeated, adding the obtained supernatant to the initial extract. 6) Aqueous extracts were filtered by centrifuging the tube filters for 5 min at 10,500 RCM. 7) The filtrate was split in 2 halves and labelled as Extract A and Extract B. 8) All extracts were frozen with liquid nitrogen and freeze dried overnight. Dried extracts were stored at −80 °C. To control the process and guarantee data quality, blank samples were prepared simultaneously to the biological samples.

protocols.name: Chromatography
protocols.description:
For the reconstitution of metabolites present in the dried extracts, 100 μl of solvent was added to each sample. For less-polar/apolar metabolites analysis by reversed-phase chromatography, a mixture of Methanol-Water 10:90 was used on the samples labelled as Extract A. For polar metabolites analysis by hydrophilic-interaction-liquid chromatography (HILIC), a mixture of Water-Acetonitrile 10:90 was used on the samples labelled as Extract B. Liquid solutions were vortexed for 30 s, then centrifuged at 20,000 RCF for 15 min at 4 °C. The supernatant was transferred in a total recovery glass LC-MS vial before their LC-MS measurement.


Untargeted analyses were performed on a high flow Acquity UPLC system coupled to a Waters Synapt G2 HDMS system (Waters Corporation, Manchester). Chromatographic separations were carried out by using both a reversed phase (RP) C18 column (Waters Acquity UPLC BEH C18 column (2.1 x 100 mm, 1.7 μm)) for semi-polar and apolar metabolites, and a hydrophilic interaction liquid chromatography column (Acquity UPLC BEH HILIC (2.1 x 100 mm, 1.7 μm)) for polar metabolites. Samples were maintained at 4 °C in the auto sampler and aliquots of 5 μl injected per run. The flow rate was set at 0.4 ml/min, and the column temperature was maintained at 40 ± 2 °C. Solvents used for separation consisted of 0.1% Formic Acid in water as mobile phase A, and 0.1% Formic acid in Acetonitrile as mobile phase B. The RP gradient elution program started running at 2% B, held for 1 min, then mobile phase B was linearly increased to 20% to minute 5, 25% in minute 6, 75% in minute 7, and 98% in minute 7.5, then was held at 98% of B until minute 8, going back to initial conditions of 98% of A in minute 9, and equilibrated the column until minute 10. The HILIC gradient elution program started running at 3% A and held for 1 min, then mobile phase A was linearly increased to 20% in 3 min, 25% in 1 min, 75% in 2 min, and 97% in 1 min, then was held for 30 s, going back to initial conditions of 97% of B in 1.5 min to later be equilibrated for 4 min.


Quality assurance (QA):

To ensure the quality of the metabolomic study, QA procedures were carried out during all the workflow steps in aims to reduce the unwanted variation regarding the pre-analytical, analytical and post-analytical phase of metabolomics[1]-[4]. To establish that the liquid chromatography high resolution mass spectrometry instrument was clean and consistent for the metabolomic studies, a series of 4–6 injections of pure solvent (injection blank sample) were run at the beginning of each sequence. To evaluate the quality of the extraction process and filter out later from the MS data the possible interferences from the extraction process, extraction blank samples were injected 3 times randomly during each sequence. To stabilize the MS platform and obtain MS control samples for the posterior data treatment, pooled quality control (QC) samples were prepared individually for each chromatographic separation technique by mixing 5 μl of each extracted sample after their reconstitution. The QC samples were injected 6 times at the beginning of each chromatographic sequence after the injections of instrumental blank samples. QC samples were also injected after each 6–8 randomized samples to monitor the stability of the analytical platform and after each extraction blank injection to preserve the stability of the MS instrument. To avoid instrumental and statistical bias, all biological samples were randomized before injection. To test the technical variability and possible carryover in the instrument during the injection of the different sequences, a quality control standard mixture (LC-MS QC STD Part number 186006963–1, Waters) was injected at the beginning and at the end of each sequence and r. t. And ions evaluated.


Refs:

[1] Beger RD, Dunn WB, Bandukwala A, Bethan B, Broadhurst D, Clish CB, Dasari S, Derr L et al. Towards quality assurance and quality control in untargeted metabolomics studies. Metabolomics. 2019 Jan 3;15(1):4. doi:10.1007/s11306-018-1460-7. PMID:30830465.

[2] Broadhurst D, Goodacre R, Reinke SN, Kuligowski J, Wilson ID, Lewis MR, Dunn WB. Guidelines and considerations for the use of system suitability and quality control samples in mass spectrometry assays applied in untargeted clinical metabolomic studies. Metabolomics. 2018;14(6):72. doi:10.1007/s11306-018-1367-3. PMID:29805336.

[3] Dunn WB, Broadhurst DI, Edison A, Guillou C, Viant MR, Bearden DW, Beger RD. Quality assurance and quality control processes: summary of a metabolomics community questionnaire Metabolomics, 13 (2017), p. 50, doi:10.1007/s11306-017-1188-9.

[4] Evans AM, O'Donovan C, Playdon M, Beecher C, Beger RD, Bowden JA, Broadhurst D, Clish CB et al. Metabolomics Quality Assurance, Quality Control Consortium (mQACC). Dissemination and analysis of the quality assurance (QA) and quality control (QC) practices of LC-MS based untargeted metabolomics practitioners. Metabolomics. 2020 Oct 12;16(10):113. doi:10.1007/s11306-020-01728-5. PMID:33044703.

protocols.name: Mass spectrometry
protocols.description: Mass spectra were collected on a Waters Synapt G2 HDMS system (Waters Corporation, Manchester) composed of an electrospray ionization (ESI) source, operated either in positive mode, an ion mobility (IM) cell and a time-of-flight detector (TOF). MS data was collected using the mobility MSe function in profile mode, full scan-over the m/z 50-1500 range. Capillary voltage was set at 3.00 kV, sampling cone 30 V, source temperature 120 °C, desolvation temperature 600 °C and desolvation gas 1000 L/h. IM and TOF cells were calibrated in advance and lock spray of leucine enkephalin was used and infused at 10 μl/min.

protocols.name: Data transformation
protocols.description: An initial pre-processing treatment, run alignment, ion detection, peak picking, isotope and adduct deconvolution, ion drift measurement, etc., was performed on the raw data using Progenesis-QI (Nonlinear dynamics) software to obtain the compounds’ metabolomic matrices for the different experiments. Workflows were processed, including on each experiment the biological samples and quality assurance samples, i.e., pooled QC, extraction blanks and injection blanks. Resultant data matrices containing the different samples and the total list of compounds detected for each experiment were inspected manually by using Microsoft Excel 2016 to filter out the non-biological information (noise, instrumental signals, compounds from the extraction process, etc.). In short, average values were calculated for each compound in the data matrix for the pooled QC, instrumental blank, and extraction blank samples, as well as the relative standard deviation (RSD) for the QC samples. Compounds with an injection or extraction blank contribution greater than 5% in respect to the average QC sample were removed. Compounds with a QC RSD value greater than 40% were removed. Before any further statistical analysis, data transformation was applied to the different data matrices, in short, K-nearest neighbours based on similar features was employed to replace missing values, and mean sample normalization, log 10 data transformation, and pareto data scaling applied to the different sets of data.

protocols.name: Metabolite identification
protocols.description:
Putative annotation of the compounds identified by the High flow-UPLC-IM-TOF-HRMS measurements on C18 and HILIC experiments was performed using the data identification window of the Progenesis QI software. Data was compared considering all potential matches using the following libraries: 1) METLIN MS/MS library 2017 for Progenesis QI plugin with a 3-ppm precursor and fragment tolerance for H = 0-150; C = 0-100; N = 0-10; O = 0-30; F = 0-4; Mg, P, S, Cl, Br, I = 0-2.2) LipidBlast library plugin with a 3-ppm precursor tolerance and 10-ppm fragment tolerance. 3) Metabolic Profiling CCS Library search plugin with a 3-ppm precursor tolerance, 10 ppm fragment tolerance, and 10% CCS tolerance.


Statistical analysis:

To establish the overall differences in the metabolic profiles within and between the historical and modern groups studied, multivariate statistical analysis, including unsupervised principal component analysis (PCA), was performed. MetaboAnalyst 5.0 (https://www.metaboanalyst.ca/) was employed for the statistical analysis of all the experiments. The quality of the established statistical models was evaluated using the R2X, R2Y, and Q2 parameters. PCA models were performed including QC samples to evaluate stability of the analytical system and the data quality, using as indicator the clustering of QC samples in successive injections during the sequences (see SI in the paper associated with this study). To visualize significant features up-regulated or down-regulated, when 2 selected groups of interest were studied, a univariate statistical test was performed, and volcano plots were drawn by transferring the fold change (FC) value of each substance peak to log2 (FC) and transferring the P value (P = 0.05) of Student's t-test to –log10(P value). By using the biomarker analysis tool of MetaboAnalyst 5.0, ROC curve-based model evaluation with inclusion of unknown samples was used to predict class for new samples, to create a biomarker model all the variables were employed using a Linear SVM model.

assays.technologyPlatform: Liquid Chromatography MS - positive - reverse phase
